title: Authors and Citation
text: Mikyung Shin. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Shin M (2022). textminingR: Text Mining Workflow Tools. R package version 0.0.1, https://mshin77.github.io/textminingR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {textminingR: Text Mining Workflow Tools},   author = {Mikyung Shin},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://mshin77.github.io/textminingR/}, }

title: Text Mining Workflow Tools
text: textminingR provides supporting workflow text mining analysis. web app incorporates quanteda (preprocess), stm (structural topic modeling), ggraph well widyr (network analysis). tidytext implemented tidy non-tidy format objects.

title: Text Mining Workflow Tools
text: can install released version textminingR CRAN : development version GitHub :

title: Text Mining Workflow Tools
text: Launch browser textminingR app:

title: Examine highest document-topic probabilities — examine_gamma_terms
code: if (FALSE) { library(tidytext)  # Tidy the document-topic combinations gamma_td <- tidy(stm_15, matrix = "gamma",                 document_names = rownames(dfm)) gamma_td %>% examine_gamma_terms(top_terms = top_terms_selected) }

title: Visualize a plot for document-topic probabilities — plot_topic_probability

text: gamma_terms tidy data frame includes document-topic probabilities. (probabilities topic per document). top_n number top n terms highest document-topic probabilities. topic_names Topic names

title: Visualize a plot for document-topic probabilities — plot_topic_probability
code: if (FALSE) { library(tidytext)  # Tidy the document-topic combinations top_terms_selected <- beta_td %>% examine_top_terms(top_n = 5) gamma_td <- tidy(stm_15, matrix = "gamma",                 document_names = rownames(dfm)) gamma_terms <- gamma_td %>% examine_gamma_terms(top_terms = top_terms_selected) gamma_terms %>% plot_topic_probability(top_n = 15) }

title: Visualize a table for document-topic probabilities — plot_topic_probability_table
code: if (FALSE) { library(tidytext)  # Tidy the document-topic combinations gamma_td <- tidy(stm_15, matrix = "gamma",                 document_names = rownames(dfm)) gamma_terms <- gamma_td %>% examine_gamma_terms(top_terms = top_terms_selected) gamma_terms %>% plot_topic_probability_table(top_n = 15) }

text: Visualize plot highest word probabilities within topic.

title: Visualize a plot for highest word probabilities within each topic — plot_topic_term
Visualize a plot for highest word probabilities within each topic — plot_topic_term
text: beta_td tidy data frame includes term (word)-topic probabilities (probabilities word per topic). top_n number top n terms frequently observed document. topic_names (Labeled) topic names ... arguments passed group_by.

title: Visualize a plot for highest word probabilities within each topic — plot_topic_term
code: if (FALSE) { library(stm) library(tidytext)  # Apply structural topic model # Convert quanteda objects to the stm package format memory.limit(24000) out <- convert(dfm, to = "stm")  K_search <- searchK(out$documents,                     out$vocab, K = c(5:10),                     data = out$meta,                     prevalence = ~ reference_type + s(year),                     verbose = TRUE)  # Run model with 15 topics stm_15 <- stm(out$documents,               out$vocab,               data = out$meta,               prevalence =  ~ reference_type + s(year),               max.em.its = 75,               init.type = 'Spectral',               K = 15,               verbose = FALSE)  # Tidy the word-topic combinations beta_td <- tidy(stm_15, document_names = rownames(dfm))  beta_td %>% plot_topic_term(top_n = 10) }

Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way. enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions). simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[. Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround. Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually : Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.
code: my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   data %>%     group_by(...) %>%     summarise(mean = mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   # Defuse   var <- enquo(var)   dots <- enquos(...)    # Inject   data %>%     group_by(!!!dots) %>%     summarise(mean = mean(!!var)) } my_var <- "disp" mtcars %>% summarise(mean = mean(.data[[my_var]])) my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   # Use `{{` to tunnel function arguments and the usual glue   # operator `{` to interpolate plain strings.   data %>%     summarise("{{ var }}_mean_{suffix}" := mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   var <- enquo(var)   prefix <- as_label(var)   data %>%     summarise("{prefix}_mean_{suffix}" := mean(!!var)) }
